thread.title: No Premier League team can beat us when we are at our best, says Tottenham's Dele Alli
thread.title_full: No Premier League team can beat us when we are at our best, says Tottenham's Dele Alli

author: Darren Lewis
title: No Premier League team can beat us when we are at our best, says Tottenham's Dele Alli
text:
No Premier League team can beat us when we are at our best, says Tottenham's Dele Alli Spurs' star midfielder on their potential, having unfinished business with the Champions League and Harry Kane Share Big game hunters Spurs are determined to return to the Champions League, says Alli (Photo: Getty) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
The title may be looking beyond them but Dele Alli wants his Tottenham side back in the Champions League. 
The north Londoners host Everton on Sunday, with Ronald Koeman’s Toffees fired up by their own pursuit of a top-six finish. 
Midfielder Alli , however, believes second-placed Spurs have unfinished business in European football’s elite competition after failing to live up to expectations in it this season after a return to the top table following six years of Europa League football. 
With a huge new stadium under construction and manager Mauricio Pochettino’s consistent side confirming last season’s promise, Alli believes Tottenham are ready to show that they can live with the best teams in the world. Alli and Spurs lost twice at Wembley to go out at the Champions League group-phase... (Photo: Getty) ...and there was more misery for him there last week as their Euro adventures ended (Photo: PA) 
“Obviously, everyone wants to be there [Champions League],” he said. “There’s tough competition in the Premier League but we fancy ourselves against anyone. So it’ll be disappointing if we don’t get back in there. 
“We’re kicking ourselves that we didn’t do better. We are confident in our ability as a team and we probably expected to go a bit further. 
“As a kid, everyone wants to play in the Champions League so it was an honour to be in it. We have the team to achieve a lot of great things. We want to be up there with the best teams in the world. But to do that we have to be in the Champions League, playing against them. 
“It’s important that we are ambitious. We know where we should be and we know what we can do as a team. 
“When we are on form and playing well, I don’t think there is anyone in the Premier League that can beat us. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Tottenham Hotspur unveil their new stadium Share this video Watch Next 
"There are no boundaries. There’s nothing we can’t do if we play as well as we know we can. 
“We’ve got to learn from every game. Hopefully in the future, maybe even this season, we’ll start winning trophies.” 
Injuries to key players such as Harry Kane and Toby Alderweireld wrecked their Champions League campaign, but Alli has refused to blame either the absences or the move to Wembley — where he got sent off last week during their Europa League exit against Gent. 
Speaking in the April edition of FourFourTwo magazine, he added: “A lot of people were saying, 'The Wembley factor' had a negative effect on us. But as a team we can’t look anywhere else. All of those fans turned up and we simply didn’t put in the performances that we knew we should have done.” 
Alli and Kane have both been key in recent weeks to maintaining Tottenham’s push for a top four place and their momentum in the FA Cup. Sub Alli made it 3-3 against Wycombe in the 89th minute before Son Heung-min's winner (Photo: Action Images via Reuters) 
It was Ali who scored a late equaliser at home to fourth-tier Wycombe in a dramatic, come-from-behind 4-3 fourth-round win. 
Then, Kane’s hat-trick at Championship Fulham set up a quarter-final home tie against League One side Millwall a week on Sunday. 
Alli also netted to help earn a draw in the Premier League at top-four race rivals Manchester City, while Kane has hit three hat-tricks in his last nine appearances in all competitions. 
Both men were also on the scoresheet last Sunday as Stoke were battered , 4-0. 
Reflecting on the understanding with club and country colleague Kane, Alli said: “We always speak about the opposition before a game. The Kane and Alli double-act is a source of optimism for Spurs fans — and England ones (Photo: Reuters) 
"We tell each other what we’re going to be looking to do, then try to put it into action. 
“He’s a fantastic player. 
"You know that if you play the ball through to him, then nine times out of ten he’s going to find the back of the net. It’s an honour to play with a striker like that. 
“His all-round play is fantastic. He holds the ball up and can bring other players into the game as well as score. 
"He works so hard too — if you do play him a bad ball, he’ll work hard to make it a good one.” poll loading
